text.tspan: predicted to have a margin of xÂ±y points. We

tspan.tspan: can model the predicted margin as a normal
and then stretch this out by
the probability of a single voter swinging the

text.tspan: This turns out to be relatively easy to compute,
and is given by the formula

tspan.tspan: This is often a very small value! For example, if
you consider a typical election with 5 million
voters, that is expected to be R+2
Some have concluded as a result that voting is
irrational, as there is a very small chance you

text.tspan: However, it's important to remember that if
you're deciding an election, you're deciding
the fate of every single person in the region
of interest! This means that if you put a value
of k on the average person's quality of life
improvement, and there's n people in this
society, the value of swinging an election is

tspan.tspan: . If we then express the number of voters
people who vote), then we have that our

text.tspan: If we assume that the previous election had
a "turnout" of 40% (typical for a US election -
keep in mind the denominator here includes
children and non-citizens), we end up with a
value of 16. That is, the value of a vote is
worth 16 times the value of winning an
election to the average person.
In other words, as long as your party winning

tspan.tspan: gives you at least 6% of the value of the

text.tspan: time and effort it takes you to vote, you
should if you care about other people in
society. Given how easy it generally is to
vote (at most a few hours of time are spent),
it is well worthwhile in almost all cases.
Now of course, the value of a vote varies a
lot depending on the circumstance. If, for
example, you don't have a competitive
election, e.g., the outcome is predicted to be
D+30 Â± 10 points and the populations are
before, you end up with E = 10-15. Here, the
value of voting is probably not that useful,
though in almost all cases, there's other,
closer elections on the ballot that are worth
voting in.
